Cards' Hammond hungry for first win vs. Cats

Louisville, Kentucky meet in top-25 matchup at KFC Yum! Center on Sunday.

Cards' Hammond hungry for first win vs. Cats

Steve Jones, swjones1@courier-journal.com 8:15 p.m. EST December 6, 2014

University of Louisville women's basketball player Sara Hammond, right, drives against Ball State player Nathalie Fontaine at the KFC Yum! Center in Louisville. U of L beat Ball State 69-56. Nov. 23, 2014.(Photo: Jessica Ebelhar/The Courier-Journal)

1 CONNECT 10 TWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE

Sara Hammond has had quite an accomplished career at the University of Louisville, but the senior forward has never beaten the University of Kentucky. She hopes to change that on Sunday.

No. 7 U of L (8-0) will host No. 13 UK (7-1) at 2 p.m. in the latest installment of this intense rivalry, and Hammond, a former Miss Basketball from Rockcastle County, wants to end the Wildcats' three-game winning streak in the series.

"Being a Kentucky girl, I bleed red and so being at home all the time, I get a lot of negative talk about that," Hammond said. "For me, Bria (Smith) and Jude (Schimmel) especially, we want to go out with just one win over UK."

U of L is coming off an impressive 86-52 win over No. 22 Iowa on Thursday, and the Cardinals have earned the respect of UK coach Matthew Mitchell. He said it was one of the most impressive performances he's seen in the past eight years.

COURIER-JOURNAL

Louisville women clobber No. 22 Iowa, 86-52

"They're just really big and athletic and they played so aggressive," Mitchell said. "They looked so cohesive, and it was a very impressive performance to watch on tape. It looked like they are really playing together. They are extremely explosive in transition, very disruptive on defense. They played a lot of man-to-man and gave Iowa a tremendous amount of problems. They have great numbers in turnover margin. They are really taking care of the ball and turning their opponents over. They're a good rebounding team, so they're very impressive."

UK's last two wins in the series have been thrilling ones. Last season in Lexington, U of L built a 14-point first-half lead, but the Wildcats rallied to win 69-64. In 2012 at the KFC Yum! Center, Janee Thompson's 3-pointer with 8.5 seconds left lifted Kentucky to a 48-47 win.

FOOTBALL: U of L likely headed to Russell Athletic Bowl

MEN'S BASKETBALL: U of L beats FIU with sharp shooting

"We all know what this rivalry is about," Hammond said. "It's kind of bragging rights for the rest of the year. ... We kind of gave it away the last couple years. I'm going to let (U of L's freshmen) know how important this game is, not just for me, but for our team. To have one top-25 team win under our belt, that's great, but to get two in one week? That's going to prove to the nation that we are a top-10 team."

UK beat Northern Kentucky 82-64 on Wednesday night behind 19 points from Kyvin Goodin-Rogers. UK is led this season by senior guard Jennifer O'Neill at 15.4 points per game. Makayla Epps averages 15.1.

U of L coach Jeff Walz said a key for his team will be to contain Kentucky's dribble penetration.

"By far (UK) is the best team we're going to play that's going to drive the ball," he said.

Kentucky leads the all-time series 32-18 but is 10-13 in Louisville.

"It's the next game on our schedule," Walz said. "It's a big game. Every one is a big game. ... They might be (No.) 13 right now, but they're a top-10 team. It's an exciting game. I hope we have a large crowd in here. It's our pack-the-house night. ... It's a great day to come out and cheer. It's going to be fun. They're all fun."

TODAY'S GAME

No. 13 Kentucky at No. 7 Louisville

2 p.m., KFC Yum! Center

Radio: WKRD-790 (U of L call), WKJK-1080 (UK call)

Online video: ESPN3

Louisville's Coach Walz talks after Iowa win.
